ns:common.topic.description: PL360 is a programming language designed by Niklaus Wirth and written by Niklaus Wirth, Joseph W. Wells, Jr., and Edwin Satterthwaite, Jr. for the IBM System/360 computer at Stanford University. A description of PL360 was published in early 1968, although the implementation was probably completed before Wirth left Stanford in 1967.
rdfs:label: PL360

ns:common.document.text: PL360 is a programming language designed by Niklaus Wirth for the IBM System/360 computer. It provides facilities for specifying exact machine language instructions and registers similar to assembly language, but also provides features commonly found in high-level languages, such as complex arithmetic expressions and control structures. Wirth used PL360 to create Algol W.\nHigh-level assembler

ns:type.object.name: PL360
